results.title: 30 Seconds to go
results.brief_description:
Shot at a Mildura television station. Details how an episode of ‘On the Land’ is broadcast by inter-cutting between an installment of the programme and conventional ‘behind the scenes’ footage of a television studio. This includes shots of a camera operator, the television station’s studio, vision-switching and so on.

Actual ‘On the Land’ programme featured, contains information on good seeds to sow and non-hormonal spraying techniques. Contains exterior shots of an orchid.

Film opens with exterior shots of Mildura that begin at river and then move into more general street scenes. This lasts for two minutes.

results.title: Green Fingers: Weed Control
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Weed Control’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to control weeds in the home garden. Cantrill shows a range of methods for managing weeds, including hoeing, mulching and herbicides, accompanied by a narrator who explains the benefits and correct techniques of each method. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: May 1955 pig carcase competition
results.brief_description:
Propaganda piece highlighting Victoria’s development as the foremost producer of pork in Australia. Competition received a record number of entries and the winning score of 93/100 for a carcase was the highest total ever in Australia. Winner was a ‘new Australian’ from Italy.

The cracases are beautifully displayed and almost fetishised as if in an art gallery. Everyone involved takes great joy, interest and pride in the meat displayed to an amusingly earnest extent. The images are high-contrast with vibrant reds and greens. A combination of the above provides a beautifully surreal quality to the piece.

Amusing sound grabs from narration such as “Here we have a veritable paradise of pork”.

Interesting ‘The End’ illustration, good for Postcards, etc.

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: [Agnotes Advertisement: 1]
results.brief_description:
Victoria’s Department of Agriculture (now Agriculture Victoria) produced Agnotes, a series of reference material for the industry with the aim to disseminate expert advise for best agricultural practices.

This advertisement was designed to increase the uptake of the Agnotes by farmers. It is one of many commercials produced for the Department of Agriculture.

results.title: Agricultural Collection
results.brief_description:
From the 1940s, the Department of Agriculture’s Film and Video Unit produced film and later video. When this unit was closed, the film and video masters and raw footage were passed to Agmedia. Agmedia produced a range of videos, principally on behalf of the Department until 1996 when it was closed. Ownership of its films and videos (including copyright) reverted to the Department of Natural Resources and Environment (the successor agency to the Department of Agriculture).
The Department of Agriculture’s Head Office Library also operated a film lending service. This was closed in 1993 and their collection of 200+ 16mm films plus videos was placed in storage.
In 1997, following the relocation of the DRNE, the collection was passed to Cinemedia for short-term storage (in controlled atmosphere) for a nominal fee. The collection consisting of 1804 film titles and over 2,000 videos, included:
· The pre 1990 Film and Video Unit master tapes and raw footage;
· The Agmedia masters and raw footage (around 750 films and tapes); and
· The library collection of 16mm films and videos
From many perspectives, this is an important collection, not just because it records Victoria’s agricultural heritage, but also because many of our filmmakers learnt their craft in making these films. There are treasures to be uncovered in the camera original footage.

results.title: Where the River Kiewa Flows
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, was created to promote the ingenuity of the Kiewa Valley diary industry, which supplied milk and butter to the people of Melbourne and Sydney.

The film highlights one farm’s introduction of a piggery to make use of their surplus milk and generate a secondary revenue stream.

results.title: Stop fruitfly (picture only)
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture and Colin Webb
results.brief_description: Picture-only print in fair/good condition. Details the way in which fruitflys can infiltrate between state borders and ruin fruit in victoria. Nicely shot with good footage of white-jacketed inspectors, people dissembarking from an Ansett plane and fruitfly-infested oranges. Also contains a shot of the ‘Frankston Marine Centre’ truck. Nicely illustrated ‘The End’.

results.title: Portland beef carcase competition 1960
results.brief_description: Promotional film highlighting the quality of Victorian beef. Shots of people looking at meat, etc throughout. Includes disturbing footage of beef carcases being hung. Great ‘The End’ title. See Also: 1955 Pig Carcase Competition at Dandenong and 1957 Pig Carcase Competition at Dandenong.

results.title: Farm Newsreel No. 1
results.brief_description: This newsreel film features agricultural activities throughout Victoria, Australia. Activities featured include hop harvesting in Myrtleford, tobacco harvesting in Ovens Valley, onion harvesting in Colac, and silage distibution in Upper Pakenham.
